journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Numerical and experimental study of combustion and emission characteristics in gasoline direct-injection compression ignition engines using intake preheating

article-meta.aff: 1Graduate School of Hanyang University, Seoul, Republic of Korea
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, Seoul, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Sungwook Park, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, 17 Haengdang-dong, Seongdong-gu, Seoul 133791, Republic of Korea. Email: parks@hanyang.ac.kr

abstract.p: This paper presents a numerical and experimental study of the combustion and emission characteristics of a gasoline direct-injection compression ignition engine using intake preheating. The gasoline direct-injection compression ignition engine was predicted to reduce emissions compared with the emissions from a conventional diesel engine. To compare the combustion and emission characteristics of the gasoline direct-injection compression ignition and diesel engines, numerical modelling was conducted using the KIVA-3V release 2 code, which is integrated with the Chemkin chemistry solver II. Numerical simulations were performed under a variety of conditions to determine the optimal conditions for gasoline direct-injection compression ignition engine operation. In order to achieve the gas pressure in the cylinder and the emission characteristics, experiments were performed using a single-cylinder engine. The simulation results agreed well with the experimental data. The gasoline autoignition was in the parcels with a lower equivalence ratio of 0.6–0.8 as opposed to the diesel autoignition parcels with a high equivalence ratio of greater than 1. The ignition delay of gasoline was longer than that of diesel; therefore, the gasoline direct-injection compression ignition engine could reduce the soot emissions. The nitrogen oxide emission levels for gasoline direct-injection compression ignition were increased because of the intake preheating.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Compression ignition (CI) engines, which have the advantages of high thermal efficiency and performance, are frequently used because of increasing oil prices and efforts to save natural resources. However, CI engines have the disadvantages of nitrogen oxide (NOx) and particulate matter (PM) emissions. Therefore, many researchers have investigated ways to reduce NOx and PM emissions and have developed strategies including low-temperature combustion (LTC), exhaust gas recirculation (EGR), diesel particulate filters (DPF), selective catalyst reduction (SCR) and common-rail direct injection (CRDI).1–5 LTC and EGR reduce NOx emissions through decreasing the combustion temperature and DPF reduces PM emissions through the filtering of emissions. SCR reduces NOx emissions effectively and the mandated further reduction in NOx emissions was achieved by most engine manufacturers with the use of SCR which required urea as the source of the reducing agent ammonia. CRDI reduces both NOx and PM emissions through the high-pressure injection of fuel. However, NOx and PM emissions must be reduced even further for the continuous use of CI engines because of stricter environmental regulations.

Meanwhile, the combustion strategy of gasoline CI has been investigated for emissions reduction. Hiraya et al.6 reported the experimental results of combustion characteristics, ignition timing and combustion duration for gasoline-fuelled homogeneous charge compression ignition (HCCI) under various compression ratios, intake temperatures and intake gas compositions. Kalghatgi et al.7 experimented to attain low PM and low NOx emissions by partially premixed autoignition gasoline in a CI engine. The results revealed that gasoline always produces much lower PM emissions than diesel fuel does under the same operating conditions because of its longer ignition delay. In addition, NOx emissions can be controlled by EGR. Ra et al.8 conducted numerical simulations and experiments with gasoline direct-injection compression ignition (GDICI) engine operation in the LTC regime and reported that the GDICI engine could reduce the NOx and PM emissions owing to the high volatility and the low cetane index of gasoline combined with a reduction in the combustion temperature through the utilization of EGR. In addition, the numerical simulations helped to explain the in-cylinder spray combustion behaviour and to identify the characteristics of GDICI engines that differ from those based on diesel-fuelled operation.

Autoignition of gasoline does not occur in diesel engines because the cetane number of gasoline is lower than that of diesel. Intake preheating or variable valve timing could be a way of utilizing the autoignition characteristic of gasoline in diesel engines. Milovanovic et al.9 reported the influence of the variable-valve-timing strategy on the HCCI engine. The results indicated that the variable-valve-timing strategy has a strong influence on the gas exchange process, which in turn influences the engine parameters and the cylinder charge properties and control of the HCCI process.

Much research has focused on gasoline HCCI.10–12 This paper presents the modelling of the combustion and emission characteristics in GDICI engines using intake preheating, which was predicted to reduce the emissions in GDICI engines compared with those in conventional diesel engines. Furthermore, the GDICI engine output was predicted to be higher than that of a gasoline engine because of the high compression ratio of the GDICI engine. The characteristics of GDICI combustion were calculated using the KIVA-3V release 2 code,13 which integrates the Chemkin chemistry solver II.14 The autoignition process of gasoline in the GDICI engine was analysed via the visualization of the temperature and equivalence ratio distribution in the cylinder. The characteristics of the GDICI engine were compared with those of a diesel engine such as the in-cylinder pressure and emissions. In addition, modelling and experiments were conducted under a variety of conditions.

sec.title: Numerical approach
sec.p: The combustion and emission characteristics in the GDICI engine using intake preheating were assessed for the modelling of the fuel spray using the KIVA-3V release 2 code that integrates the Chemkin chemistry solver II. Table 1 shows the models used for the simulations, and details are given below.

caption.p: Numerical model.

fn.p: PRF: primary reference fuel; ERC: Engine Research Center; KH–RT: (Kelvin–Helmholtz)–(Rayleigh–Taylor); NOx: nitrogen oxides; GRI: Gas Research Institute.

sec.title: Spray model
sec.p: The (Kelvin–Helmholtz (KH))–(Rayleigh–Taylor (RT)) model15 was used for simulating the spray process. This model is a hybrid model which combines the KH model and the RT model. The KH model calculates the primary break-up which occurs on the liquid jet surface near the nozzle hole, and the combined KH–RT model was used to calculate the secondary break-up. The primary break-up occurs because of a growing KH instability wave which is generated by the turbulence flow inside the nozzle hole. In this model, it is assumed that both air and the fuel are incompressible fluids and that air is an inviscid fluid. The KH instability wave is calculated from

The Ohnesorge number Z, the Taylor number Ta, the Weber number We and the radius r0 are variables. The radius of a new droplet is calculated from
where B0=0.61.

Then, the droplet breaks up into smaller child droplets because of the aerodynamic force due to the relative velocity between the droplet and the ambient gas phase. The density of air is ignored because it is very small compared with the density of the fuel.

sec.title: Combustion model
sec.p: In order to simulate the ignition and combustion process of fuel, the Chemkin chemistry solver II was coupled with the KIVA-3V release 2 code. The gasoline and diesel fuels are represented by iso-octane and n-heptane respectively. It is widely accepted that the ignition and combustion characteristics of iso-octane and n-heptane represent those of gasoline and diesel fuels.16–18 In order to calculate the chemical kinetics of iso-octane and n-heptane combustion, the primary reference fuel (PRF) mechanism19 and the reduced Engine research Center (ERC) mechanism20 were used respectively. 41 species and 130 reactions composed the PRF mechanism, and 30 species and 65 reactions composed the reduced ERC mechanism. Data from HCCI engine experiments and shock tube tests by Ra et al. who reported the major reactions which affect the ignition delay were used to validate the PRF mechanism.

The Gas Research Institute (GRI) nitric oxide (NO) mechanism21 was used to calculate the formation of NOx. This mechanism is composed of four species and nine reactions that were added to the PRF and the reduced ERC mechanisms. The four species were N, NO, NO2 and N2O and the nine reactions were

where the total amount of NOx emissions is determined as the sum of the NO and NO2 emissions. This assumption is supported by the fact that NOx emissions are mainly composed of NO and NO2 emissions.22

In addition, a two-step phenomenological model suggested by Hiroyasu and Kadota23 was used to predict the soot emissions. This model calculates the rates of soot formation and soot oxidation, such that the total amount of soot emissions is determined as the difference calculated from
First, the equation used for soot formation is the Arrhenius equation
and acetylene is used as the precursor.
Second, soot formation is calculated by the Nagle and Strickland–Constable model as
where Esf=12,500cal/mol, Asf=500, ρs=2g/cm3 and Ds=2.5×10−6cm.

sec.title: Computational conditions
sec.p: Experiments were performed using a single-cylinder diesel engine, and the specifications of the test engine are indicated in Table 2. The spray angle was 156° and the injector had six holes. As the injector has six holes, the 60° sector mesh for top dead centre (TDC) shown in Figure 1 was used. The number of parcels for bottom dead centre was 7356, and the compression ratio was adjusted by the crevice volume. Simulations were performed from intake valve closed (IVC) to exhaust valve open. The operation conditions for gasoline- and diesel-fuelled experiments were the same, but the intake temperature was 200 °C for gasoline. Therefore, the cylinder gas pressure of the gasoline-fuelled experiments was slightly higher than that of the diesel-fuelled experiments at IVC. The injection timing was defined as the start of energizing (SOE) time. Detailed operation conditions of the numerical simulations are the same as those of experiments, as indicated in Table 3.

caption.p: Specifications of the test engine.

fn.p: DOHC: dual-overhead-cam shaft; CA: crank angle; BTDC: before top dead centre; ATDC: after top dead centre.

caption.p: Experimental operation conditions.

fn.p: IVC: intake valve closed; SOE: start of energizing; CA: crank angle; BTDC: before top dead centre.

caption.p: Computational mesh for TDC.

sec.title: Experimental set-up
sec.p: The experimental apparatus used for this study is illustrated in Figure 2. A naturally aspirated single-cylinder diesel engine with a displacement volume of 373.3 cm3 and a compression ratio of 17.8 was used. The engine speed was controlled using a d.c. dynamometer (55 kW). In addition, the fuels used for the experiments were gasoline and diesel. The property values of the fuel are indicated in Table 4.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the experimental apparatus.
NOx: nitrogen oxides: HC: hydrocarbon; CO: carbon monoxide.
Property values of the fuels for the experiment.

sec.p: The intake air was controlled using an air compressor and an air flow meter. For gasoline autoignition in the diesel engine, the intake air was heated to 200 °C using a heating coil (5 kW) in the intake pipe. The fuel was injected directly into the cylinder with a common-rail system (Bosch) and the injection pressure was controlled using a couple of high-pressure pumps (Haskel HSF-300) arranged in a row. In addition, an injector driver (TEMS TDA 3300) with a crank angle (CA) sensor was used to control the injection timing and injection duration.

The in-cylinder pressure data were measured using a piezoelectric pressure transducer (Kistler 6057A80) coupled to a charge amplifier (Kistler 5018A) and then acquired with a data acquisition board (National Instruments PCI-MIO-16E-1). The exhaust emissions were analysed using a smoke meter (AVL 415S) and exhaust gas analyser (Horiba MEXA-554JKNOx).24

sec.title: Combustion characteristics of the GDICI engine
sec.p: Figure 3(a) shows the in-cylinder pressures and the heat release rates of diesel and n-heptane, and Figure 3(b) the in-cylinder pressures and the heat release rates of gasoline and iso-octane. The in-cylinder pressure is the averaged pressure data of collected 300 replicated cycles. Also, Figure 3(a) shows the coefficient of variation according to the SOE. Combustion was stable without knocking. As shown in Figure 3, the simulation results were validated with the experimental data and the differences in the pressure histories and in the ignition times were within acceptable ranges. The pressure data of simulations have ±3% error compared with those of experiments. However, the peak value of heat release rate for the simulation was higher than that for the experiment owing to a difference in calculation methods. In the simulation, the heat release rate was calculated as the sum of the generated heat from sprayed fuel combustion in each cell, while for the experiment the heat release rate was calculated on the basis of the achieved pressure value from the pressure sensor. For this reason, the heat release rate values of the simulation contain the heat transfer and mechanical loss. Therefore, the maximum values and overall heat release from the simulation results were higher than those from the experiment results. Considering this difference, the predicted simulation results are reliable.

caption.p: Validation of the in-cylinder pressure and heat release rate in engine experiments: (a) diesel and n-heptane; (b) gasoline and iso-octane.
SOE: start of energizing; Exp.: experiment; Cal.: calculation; ATDC: after top dead centre.

sec.p: Based on the pressure history, the in-cylinder pressure of gasoline increases steeply compared with that of diesel during combustion. Therefore, the combustion time of gasoline was shorter and the peak value of the heat release rate was higher than those of diesel owing to the difference in the cetane numbers of the fuels. Because gasoline has a lower cetane number than diesel does, the ignition delay of gasoline is longer; therefore, the injected fuel was mixed well with the air and rapid combustion ocurred.

The inhomogeneity value suggested by Sun and Reitz25 was calculated to analyse the air–fuel mixture quality, which was estimated through the standard deviation (SD) of the equivalence ratio in the combustion chamber. The inhomogeneity value is calculated as
with the SD given by

The equivalence ratio in each cell is calculated using the concentrations of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen atoms. The statistical mean value and SD of the equivalence ratio are calculated over the whole combustion chamber. Finally, the normalized standard deviation (NSD) of the equivalence ratio is calculated from

as the inhomogeneity value. Therefore, a lower inhomogeneity value denotes a higher mixture quality. However, the inhomogeneity value is only valid before ignition. Figure 4 shows the inhomogeneity of iso-octane and n-heptane according to the CA. Before ignition the inhomogeneity of iso-octane is higher than that of n-heptane. Therefore, it can be seen that the gasoline spray shows an advanced mixing performance compared with that of the diesel spray.

caption.p: Inhomogeneity (NSD) histories of iso-octane and n-heptane.
NSD: normalized standard deviatioon; SOE: start of energizing; ATDC: after top dead centre.

sec.title: Ignition process of the GDICI engine
sec.p: In order to analyse the autoignition processes of gasoline and diesel, the in-cylinder distributions of the equivalence ratio and temperature with different injection timings at 20° CA BTDC and 10° CA BTDC were examined, as shown in Figure 5 and Figure 6 respectively.

caption.p: In-cylinder distributions of the equivalence ratio and temperature for iso-octane and n-heptane at 20° CA BTDC.
SOE: start of energizing; BTDC: before top dead centre.
In-cylinder distributions of the equivalence ratio and temperature for iso-octane and n-heptane at 10° CA BTDC.
SOE: start of energizing; BTDC: before top dead centre.

sec.p: The injected fuel formed a rich region on the piston bowl at 10° CA BTDC with gasoline injection timing at 20° CA BTDC. This rich region moved up along the bottom of piston bowl at 7° CA BTDC such that the combustion chamber could be divided into three parts: the rich region, the lean region and the boundary region. On the other hand, it was seen that the injected fuel formed the rich region on the piston bowl at 14° CA BTDC in diesel injection timing at 20° CA BTDC. The combustion chamber could also be divided into the same three rich, lean and boundary regions.

Meanwhile, the autoignition time was confirmed by observing the temperature distribution. At 10° CA BTDC with the gasoline injection timing at 20° CA BTDC, the temperature of the rich region was lower than those of the other regions because fuel evaporation and autoignition occurred in the boundary region at 6° CA BTDC. Then, the combustion flame diffused rapidly. Likewise, autoignition occurred in the boundary region with the gasoline injection timing at 10° CA BTDC. At this moment, the equivalence ratio of the boundary region was approximately18,26 0.6–0.8. The more the injection timing advances, the longer is the ignition delay, which would be expected to affect the amount of soot emissions. However, autoignition of diesel occurred differently in the rich region from gasoline injection. The autoignition of gasoline in the boundary region which generated an equivalence ratio of 0.6–0.8 was opposed to the autoignition of diesel in the rich region with an equivalence ratio greater than 1. Likewise, autoignition occurred in the rich region with the diesel injection timing at 10° CA BTDC. The ignition delays for diesel injection timing at 20° CA BTDC and 10° CA BTDC were 10° CA and 8° CA respectively. The ignition delay of gasoline fuel was at most 4° CA longer relative to that of diesel fuel, as shown in Figure 6(b).

The autoignition of gasoline in the boundary region with an equivalence ratio of 0.6–0.8 could be explained on the basis of the iso-octane ignition phenomenon studied by Walton et al.,27 who performed an experimental investigation of the iso-octane ignition delay using a rapid compression facility. In this study, the effects of the pressure, temperature, equivalence ratio, oxygen mole fraction and fuel mole fraction on the ignition delay of iso-octane were reported, and it was suggested thet the equation of ignition delay by the regression analysis is

where τing (ms) is the ignition delay, P (atm) is the pressure, φ is the equivalence ratio, xO2 (%) is the oxygen mole fraction, R (cal/mol K) is the universal gas constant and T (K) is the temperature.

Figure 7 is the temperature–equivalence ratio contour map for the ignition delay of the iso-octane equation (19). In order to isolate the effects of the pressure and the oxygen mole fraction, the pressure and the oxygen mole fraction were set at a stable 15 atm and 21% respectively. Through this contour map, it can be seen that not all the high-equivalence-ratio regions were short-ignition-delay regions. In Figures 5 and 6, the temperature of the rich region is lower than the temperature of the boundary region because of the latent heat of evaporation. Therefore, autoignition of gasoline occurred in the boundary region with an equivalence ratio of 0.6–0.8 because of the influence of the higher temperature. Considering both the equivalence ratio and the temperature, the ignition delay of iso-octane would be the shortest in the boundary region.

caption.p: Temperature–equivalence ratio contour map for the ignition delay of iso-octane.
Ign: ignition.

sec.title: Effect of the intake preheating and emission characteristics
sec.p: Figure 8(a) and (b) shows the amounts of NOx and soot emissions respectively from GDICI engines according to the SOE timing. To validate the GRI NOx mechanism and the two-step phenomenological soot model, the simulation and experimental results are shown together. The predicted NOx and soot emission results follow the same trends as shown in the experimental results.

caption.p: Amount of emissions in the GDICI engine according to the SOE timing: (a) NOx; (b) soot.
EI: emissions index: NOx: nitrogen oxides; Exp.: experiment; Cal.: calculation; EGR: exhaust gas recirculation; SOE: start of energizing; ATDC: after top dead centre.

sec.p: First, the NOx emission level with gasoline was higher than that with diesel, as shown in Figure 8(a). These results were caused by intake preheating for gasoline autoignition and combustion temperature increases under the influence of intake preheating. Therefore, the GDICI engine using intake preheating increases the NOx emissions. However, it can be expected that a reduction in the NOx emissions can be achieved in GDICI engines through the use of the EGR system. The simulation results of the reduced NOx emissions in the GDICI engine with EGR were at 50%, as shown in Figure 8(a). Ra et al.8 reported that the reduction in the NOx emissions could be achieved in GDICI engines with EGR systems in the LTC regime. Therefore, the increased NOx emissions can be reduced using an EGR system under the influence of intake preheating. In addition, the more advanced injection timing increased the NOx emissions because the advanced injection timing generates a longer ignition delay and rapid combustion occurs, resulting from the longer ignition delay. Therefore, NOx emissions were increased by the high temperature and high pressure during the combustion.

Second, the soot emission level with gasoline was lower than that with diesel, as shown in Figure 8(b). There are two reasons for this reduction in the soot emissions: one is the low equivalence ratio and the other is the high temperature of combustion.28 As mentioned above, the gasoline ignition delay was 4° longer than the diesel ignition delay, resulting in a better mixture quality and a reduction in the soot emissions. In addition, a high temperature of combustion under the influence of intake preheating would decrease the soot emissions. However, the peak temperature of gasoline combustion was 1900 K, which is too low to effect a reduction in the soot emissions. Therefore, the longer ignition delay of gasoline decreases the soot emissions.16,29Figure 9 shows the soot formation characteristics of iso-octane and n-heptane according to the CA. At the beginning of combustion, a large number of soot particles are formed in the rich region and oxidize as the combustion develops and the leftover particles become the soot emissions. Fewer soot particles were formed in the gasoline-fuelled case than in the diesel-fuelled experiments. Synthetically, a GDICI engine can markedly reduce the soot emissions in all cases of SOE timing.

caption.p: Soot formation characteristics of iso-octane and n-heptane according to the CA.
SOE: start of energizing; ATDC: after top dead centre.

sec.title: Optimal conditions for GDICI engine operation
sec.p: Numerical simulations were performed under a variety of conditions to determine the optimal conditions for GDICI engine operation. Figures 10, 11 and 12 show the oxygen concentration–SOE contour maps for the indicated mean effective pressure (IMEP), for the NOx emissions and for the soot emissions respectively. In Figures 10(a), 11(a) and 12(a) the intake temperature is 200 °C and in Figures 10(b), 11(b) and 12(b) the intake temperature is 300 °C. In Figure 10(b), while the range of possible operating conditions was extensive, the IMEP was low. At the same cylinder volume and pressure, the mole of intake air was becoming smaller with increasing intake temperature. Overall, the IMEP is low as a whole because of insufficient combustion, and the overall high soot emission level with increasing intake temperature also occurs for this same reason. In Figure 11, the NOx emission levels increased with increasing intake temperature. Concerning these results, the most optimal condition is an intake temperature of 200 °C compared with an intake temperature of 300 °C.

caption.p: Oxygen concentration–SOE contour map for the IMEP in the GDICI engine: (a) intake temperature, 200 °C; (b) intake temperature, 300 °C.
SOE: start of energizing; ATDC: after top dead centre; IMEP: indicated mean effective pressure.
Oxygen concentration–SOE contour map for NOx emissions in the GDICI engine: (a) intake temperature, 200 °C; (b) intake temperature, 300 °C.
SOE: start of energizing; ATDC: after top dead centre; NOx: nitrogen oxides.
Oxygen concentration–SOE contour map for soot emissions in the GDICI engine: (a) intake temperature, 200 °C; (b) intake temperature, 300 °C.
SOE: start of energizing; ATDC: after top dead centre; NOx: nitrogen oxides.

sec.p: Two high-IMEP ranges are shown in Figure 10(a). Both ranges have conditions where the ignition occurred near TDC. One was below a 13% oxygen concentration with a 50– 60° CA BTDC SOE; the other was above a 13% oxygen concentration with a 5–25° CA BTDC SOE. The former resulted in high IMEP values because the ignition delay was very long under the influence of low oxygen concentrations and the occurrence of ignition near TDC. In addition, the NOx emissions increased as the oxygen concentration increased, as shown in Figure 11. The NOx emission level was especially high near 20° CA BTDC SOE because of the maximum in-cylinder pressure and temperature. The soot emissions decreased as the oxygen concentration increased, as shown in Figure 12, and this was especially high near 10° CA BTDC SOE.

Taken together, these results indicate that the IMEP is high and the NOx and soot emissions are low under specific operating conditions when the condition parameters are below 13% oxygen and 50– 60° CA BTDC SOE. The other condition parameters are a 13–18% oxygen concentration and 5– 25° CA BTDC SOE. In conclusion, these two ranges represent the optimal conditions for GDICI engine operation.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The present study analysed the combustion and emission characteristics of a GDICI engine compared with those of a diesel engine. Numerical modelling was performed using the KIVA-3V release 2 code which integrates Chemkin chemistry solver II. The simulation results were validated with experimental results and the conclusions of the present study can be summarized as follows.

list-item.p: The GDICI engine operated stably through intake preheating at 200 °C. The gasoline fuel has a high autoignition temperature, and it is difficult for autoignition to occur in a conventional diesel engine. However, the gasoline fuel combusted stably in the conventional diesel engine without knocking through intake preheating.

The autoignition of gasoline occurred in the region with an equivalence ratio of 0.6–0.8. The autoignition of gasoline in the boundary region occurred with an equivalence ratio of 0.6–0.8 as opposed to the autoignition of diesel in the rich region with an equivalence ratio greater than 1.
The ignition delay of gasoline was longer than that of diesel. The ignition delay of gasoline was 10–14° CA and that of diesel was 9–10° CA.

NOx emission was increased in the GDICI engine. Under the influence of intake preheating, the in-cylinder temperature rose and the NOx emissions increased compared with those in the conventional diesel engine.

The GDICI engine can markedly reduce soot emissions in all cases of SOE timing. It was confirmed that the sprayed gasoline mixed better with air than sprayed diesel did on the basis of the inhomogeneity analysis. It was shown that the longer ignition delay of gasoline decreases soot emissions.

The IMEP is high and the NOx and soot emissions are low under the specific operating conditions. One condition has below 13% oxygen concentration and 50–60° CA BTDC SOE; the other condition has 13–18% oxygen concentration and 5–25° CA BTDC SOE. These two ranges are the optimal conditions for GDICI engine operation.
